thread.title: Rookie’s stunning CV, Tiger’s cheeky date bet
thread.title_full: Rookie’s stunning CV, Tiger’s cheeky date bet

title: Rookie’s stunning CV, Tiger’s cheeky date bet
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS TYRELL Fuimaono has no idea whether he will play an NRL game this year. 
He hopes he does, sure. But that will be solely up to South Sydney coach Michael Maguire. 
What the 20-year-old Bunnies recruit does know is that if this rugby league caper doesn’t work out, he has plenty of other career paths laying in front of him. 
In fact Fuimaono has more fingers in more pies than most people his age. More than most professional sportsmen of any age, for that matter. 
Don’t be mistaken — he’s always wanted to play rugby league for a living. But that hasn’t stopped him preparing for a life outside football if and when that time comes. 
Fuimaono is midway through a degree in business commerce at Western Sydney University. He’s interested in property development. 
Aside from that, he’s planning to apply for a real estate licence in the not too distant future, and he’s studying for a Certificate 4 in fitness. 
“A broad range, just keeping my mind open to anything,” the switched-on Fuimaono tells foxsports.com.au . 
“I’m fortunate to be a rugby league player. We do have a lot of opportunities and help off the field, so one thing I’ve always said is to take it with both hands if someone is encouraging or providing you (an opportunity).” Tyrell Fuimaono playing for NSW under 20s. Source: Supplied 
Fuimaono credits the NRL’s School to Work program — particularly the work done with indigenous children — for his eagerness and passion to follow opportunities outside football. 
It was with the help of NRL education officers that he gained early entry into university and began his tertiary studies. 
He has a simple message for any young indigenous person wanting to follow a similar path. 
“Never say no,” he said. 
“Just jump at it, take every opportunity that you’re given because we’re very fortunate to get that. Not everyone is provided with that so never say no.” 
Check out the social side of the game in this week’s edition of NRL Confidential! 
PRE-SEASON PRANKS 
South Sydney playmaker Adam Reynolds gave teammate Jason Clark a fright when he asked him to check under his car. A post shared by Adam Reynolds (@rendiggiti7) on Feb 17, 2017 at 6:36pm PST 
BIG PANTHER’S BIG HEART 
Penrith forward Leilani Latu will run seven kilometres in the Avid Runner Bay Run to raise money for Kingdom Elevated Youth. 
The money Latu and his fellow runners raise will buy sports equipment and help fund youth camps. We ❤️️ a Leilani Latu charge! Now he's running 7kms to raise money for his youth group: https://t.co/kz6mAnCKVA #pantherpride 🐾 pic.twitter.com/3rN5J2gUmq — Penrith Panthers (@PenrithPanthers) February 19, 2017 
IT’S A TOUGH BUSINESS 
The NRL season hasn’t even kicked off yet and already Eels skipper Tim Mannah is sporting a nice black eye. 
The Eels forward copped a head clash during Saturday’s trial against Penrith. 
The tough prop went off to get stitched up then ran back onto the field like nothing had happened. — Tim Mannah (@tim_mannah) February 18, 2017 
STITCHED UP 
Former NRL player Cory Paterson had to get his wife to mend a nasty gash above his eye. Talk about a stitch-up. Perks of having a wife who's a nurse 👌🏼👍🏼 pic.twitter.com/n9lan88IYz — Cory Paterson (@CoryPato) February 19, 2017 
TITAN’S CHEEKY FAREWELL 
Zeb Taia had his last training with Gold Coast this week before he flies to England to restart life in the Super League. 
Konrad Hurrell took the chance to take a cheeky dig at his mate on Instagram, while saying goodbye in his own way. A post shared by koni_Naala (@koni_hurrell) on Feb 20, 2017 at 11:13pm PST 
TIGER TRIES HIS LUCK 
By now we’re sure you’ve heard of Canadian tennis star Eugenie Bouchard, who went on a date with a fan after he won a Twitter bet during the Super Bowl. 
Well, Wests Tigers prop Ava Seumanufagai thought he’d try a similar approach after meeting UFC star Miesha Tate. If Patriots win we go on a date ? @MieshaTate pic.twitter.com/XjFr5R9i6r — Ava Seumanufagai (@Ava_seu) February 18, 2017 
UNDER THE KNIFE 
Australian star Kezie Apps is in the wars but keeping positive after a brutal time in Auckland earlier this month for the three-Test women’s series. 
Apps broke a leg and had three stitches put in her head, and went under the knife this week to have six screws and a metal plate inserted. Surgery all done 🙌 6 screws and a plate later but it all went well #bringonrehab @NRL @AusJillaroos pic.twitter.com/4jJn5JDekF 
Do you live in Queensland? Want to meet a bunch of NRL legends and talk footy with them? Tap here to find out how you can, thanks to FOX SPORTS’ brand new 24/7 rugby league channel, FOX LEAGUE.
